At the back was the old stuff, he really didn't like to look at it... at all. Chewing gum and cigarette butts were his daily dose, yet near the back of the vending machine lay the untraditionally textured oozes that would have consisted of a mixture of vile, rotten, melted and exploded confectioneries; the sweet, the sour and the salty. "James is in charge of a gang of street punks called The Lost Boys, whose main goal is to make money by selling candy. He doesn't know what's going on here though, so he just stands there and looks at them with an unreadable expression on his face." James' expression was not quite blank. It had some hint of confusion mixed in with it. His mouth was open slightly, revealing two sharp teeth which were probably sharper than any other human's. There was also a small scar above his left eye, which could be seen through his black sunglasses.

HOW TO MAKE: Super Easy Kung Pao Shrimp
Ingredients:
3 Tablespoons Low Sodium Soy Sauce
3 Tablespoons Water
1 teaspoon Cornstarch
1 teaspoon Rice Wine Vinegar
18 teaspoons Sesame Oil
1/4 teaspoons Fresh Ginger, Minced
1/2 teaspoons Sriracha (or More To Taste If You Like It Spicy)
1 Tablespoon Oil
1/4 cups Red Bell Pepper, Diced
1/4 cups Green Bell Pepper, Diced
12 ounces, weight Large Shrimp, Peeled With The Tails Off
2 cloves Garlic, Minced
Chopped Peanuts, For Serving
Green Onions, For Garnish (optional)
Sesame Seeds, For Garnish (optional). For the sauce: Whisk all of the ingredients together in a small bowl. Set aside. For the shrimp: Heat oil in a large skillet. In a medium bowl, whisk together soy sauce, water, corn starch, rice wine vinegar, ginger, sriracha, and sesame oil. Set aside. Place skillet over medium high heat and add in the shrimp mixture. Stir fry for 5 to 7 minutes or until shrimp turns translucent. Turn off heat and let shrimp sit for 10 minutes before serving.

HOW TO MAKE: Rosemary Mustard Chicken
Ingredients:
300 grams Chicken thigh meat
1 pinch of each Salt and pepper
1 tbsp Butter (to finish)
1 * Plastic bag
2 sheets * Aluminum foil
1 tbsp Olive oil
1 tbsp Sake
1 tbsp Water
1 tbsp Grainy mustard
1 tbsp Soy sauce
1 tsp Honey (or sugar)
2 sprigs Rosemary (fresh). Combine the marinade ingredients marked (olive oil, sake, water, grainy mustard, soy sauce, honey or sugar) and mix well together. Cut the chicken into bite sized pieces and season with salt and pepper. When hot add the chicken and fry until golden brown on both sides. Remove from the pan to a paper towel lined plate. Repeat with remaining chicken pieces. Heat up another frying pan over medium-high heat. Add the butter and sesame seeds. Cook until golden brown on both sides. Once done, remove from the pan to a paper towel lined plate.

HOW TO MAKE: Tasty Spice Burgers
Ingredients:
2 lbs ground beef
14 cup seasoned bread crumbs
1 teaspoon Worcestershire sauce
1 teaspoon minced garlic or 1 teaspoon Mrs. Dash garlic and herb seasoning
2 teaspoons McCormick's Montreal Brand steak seasoning
12 teaspoon chili powder
2 teaspoons ketchup
1 teaspoon mustard
12 teaspoon mrs. dash italian seasoning or 12 teaspoon oregano
1 teaspoon Season-All salt (optional)
12 teaspoon cayenne pepper (optional)
1 teaspoon onion powder
12 teaspoon cajun seasoning
1 pinch basil
1 pinch cumin (optional)
2 teaspoons barbecue sauce (recommend Jack Daniels No. 7)
1 egg (optional to prevent breaking if necessary)
4 slices American cheese (optional). Combine all ingredients in large bowl and mix well with clean hands. Patty out burgers into patties about 1/2" thick or to your liking. Be sure to take into consideration the amount of fat in the beef as leaner meat will not shrink as much. Add onions and saute until soft and translucent. Stir in tomatoes and cook for another 2 minutes. Add seasonings and stir well. Reduce heat to low and cover. Cook for 20 minutes. Serve with fresh cilantro and chopped lettuce.

The most depressing part about the end of the Christmas season is not after all the presents are opened and all the smiling and laughing over new toys stops. It's not the now silent workshops temporarily empty and idle as the elves take a well-earned break. It's not when I see everyone box up the decorations. It's January. Alone in the North I spent January in reverent silence. I learned how to sit down and watch something without getting on my knees, learning some basic observation skills while feeling like an asshole for thinking this way at that moment. You've got to learn it, somehow: how to stare into space like it isn't your face. I did this with winter, too. December always felt lonely even though it was followed by two lovely holiday weekends during which there were picnics with family (my stepfather and grandmother) and one insane-paced day trip from "Ithaca" to Ottawa. In mid December we would go to North Dakota where we could literally throw away the tents and stock up on warm clothing.

1 cup dry white wine
1 cup water
1/4 cup chopped shallots
2 tablespoons white wine vinegar
4 garlic cloves, crushed with side of knife
40 fresh mussels, scrubbed, debearded

12 teaspoon salt

fresh tarragon sprig

red bell pepper, cut into strips

chives.

DOCUMENT:
On Sunday, Serbia will make its third attempt this year to elect a new president, but disillusionment with political infighting is so intense that low voter turnout could once again invalidate the ballot. Opinion polls suggest that Vojislav Kostunica, a conservative nationalist and currently president of the Yugoslav federation grouping Serbia and Montenegro, will pick up two-thirds of the vote to defeat two more radical nationalist candidates. But unless more than half of the electorate votes the result will be annulled -- as it was in October when Mr. Kostunica won a runoff against Miroljub Labus, a pro-Western liberal, by a similar margin. Serbia needs a new president to replace Milan Milutinovic, an associate of the ousted Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic. He faces trial on war crimes charges once his term expires at the end of the month. If a successor is not elected, the speaker of Parliament would take over temporarily under the old Constitution, which would then most likely be amended so parliamentary deputies can choose the new president. The likely failure of Sunday's vote is the result of a long-running feud between Mr. Kostunica and the Serbian prime minister, Zoran Djindjic. The two forged a reformist alliance to topple Mr. Milosevic two years ago but have since refused to cooperate, derailing the reform process. The sacking of Croatia's Prime Minister Ivo Sanader last week underscores tensions. On Sunday Mr. Djurdjic used nationalist rhetoric against Croatian leaders who he accused of supporting asylum seekers who seek to enter Serbia illegally from neighboring countries.
